## Classic Determinants {.smaller}  

- **Religious Factors** (Jelen & Wilcox, 2003; Cook, 2019)  
  - **Affiliation**: Denominational differences (Catholic/Protestant vs Jewish/mainline)  
  - **Religiosity**: Outweighs affiliation differences (Lynxwiler, 1999; Wilcox, 1992)  

- **Socioeconomic Variables** 
  - **Education & Income**: Socioeconomic privilege → abortion rights support (Granberg & Granberg, 1980)  
  
- **Political Alignment** 
  - **Partisan sorting**: Liberal/Democrat vs. Conservative/Republican (Hess & Rueb, 2005)  
  - **Bidirectional relationship**: Abortion attitudes drive party switching (e.g., 1992 pro-choice Republicans; Abramowitz, 1995)   
  
---

## Theoretical Puzzle {.smaller}

<div style="margin-bottom: 100px;"></div>

::: {.fragment .fade-in style="margin-top: 20px; text-align: center;"}
**Despite numerous shifts in political discourse...**
:::

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

::: {.fragment .fade-in style="margin-top: 20px; text-align: center;"}
- The core predictors of abortion attitudes have remained relatively stable over time.
:::

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

::: {.fragment .fade-in style="margin-top: 20px; text-align: center;"}
**Contrasting with**:

- Evolving views on other issues (same-sex marriage, cannabis) (Adamczyk et al., 2020)

:::

---

## Emerging Determinants {.smaller}
### Lifestyle Politics? 

<div style="margin-bottom: 30px;"></div>

::: {.fragment .fade-in}

**Political Polarization Context**

- Growing partisan divide on abortion policy (Abramowitz & Saunders, 2008)
- Ideological polarization intensifying social identities (Mason, 2018)
- Affective polarization increasing social distance (Iyengar et al., 2012, 2019)

:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in style="margin-top: 30px;"}

**Why Study Lifestyle Habits?**

- Emergence of lifestyle politics as analytical framework (DellaPosta et al., 2015)
- Reflect deeper ideological alignments in everyday choices (Husic-Mehmedovic et al., 2015)
  - Non-political choices becoming political signals 

:::

## Results {.smaller transition=none}
### Interaction Analysis

<div style="margin-bottom: 40px;"></div>

For each interaction, we calculated:

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

**Difference Score Effect**: Difference between the classic model (main predictors of abortion) and the interaction model (classic model × lifestyle variables).

<div style="margin-bottom: 60px;"></div>

$$\Delta_{effect} = |\beta_{classic \times lifestyle} - \beta_{classic}|$$

## Results {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
- **Strong Republican Identity**
  - Drinking Craft Beer: Weakens the negative relationship (-0.139**)
  - Owning Prius: Weakens the negative relationship (-0.139***)
- **Soft Republican Identity**
  - Hunting Frequency: Strengthens the negative relationship (0.559**)
  - Motorized Activities: Strengthens the negative relationship (0.476***)
 
:::


::: {.column width="50%"}

- **Religiosity**
  - Drinking Craft Beer: Weakens the negative relationship (-0.132*)
  - Video Game Playing: Weakens the negative relationship (-0.057*)

:::
::::



## Conclusion {.smaller}

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

::: {.incremental}
- **Traditional factors remain strong predictors, but...**

<div style="margin-bottom: 20px;"></div>

- **Lifestyle factors seem to have an effect on abortion attitudes**
  - Specifically when interacting with « classic » predictors
  
:::

<div style="margin-bottom: 20px;"></div>

::: {.incremental}

- **Limitations**
  - Wording of our DV (single item measuring abortion attitudes)
  - Abortion attitudes are more complex and often depend on the context
  - A question battery would have been preferable 

<div style="margin-bottom: 20px;"></div>

- **Comments/critiques on our methodology?**
  - Novel approach to interaction analysis between lifestyle and predictors of abortion attitudes 
  - Does our approach adequately address the contextual nature of these relationships?

:::
